awd_titl_txt: Conference: USA-UK-China-Israel Workshop on Frontiers in Ecology and Evolution of Infectious Diseases
awd_abstract_narration:
This award will fund travel by fifteen US researchers to a workshop to enhance international collaborations in among scientists from the US, UK, Israel, and China who work on the ecology and evolution of infectious diseases. The workshop will be held at the Wellcome Trust, London, UK, on May 22-23, 2024. The SARS-CoV-2 pandemic and other infectious disease outbreaks in recent decades have resulted in substantial losses of economy, human life, and the society. Emergence, transmission, spread, and persistence of infectious diseases in the pathogen - host (plant, animal, and human) - environmental systems (PHES) is complex and dynamic. In addition to pathogen evolution, most of these infectious diseases involve multiple hosts and transmission pathways that are affected by many rapidly changing socio-economic and environmental factors. This workshop will broaden and strengthen international collaboration among researchers and institutions. The participants will review, assess, and understand recent research progresses in infectious disease ecology and evolution. They will identify major gaps in data, information, and knowledge, discuss new and major research opportunities, identify research priority areas, and discuss possible mechanisms and pathways for joint research and education activities. The workshop will include a diverse groupe of researchers from a variety of institutions and career stages.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The COVID-19 and other major infectious disease outbreaks in the past centuries have resulted in substantial losses of economy and human life. Emergence, transmission, spillover, spread, and persistence of infectious diseases in the pathogen – host/vector - environmental systems (PHVES) is complex and dynamic. It is an imperative and a grand challenge for our society to predict and prevent emergence, transmission, spread, and persistence of infectious diseases. The COVID-19 pandemic has also clearly demonstrated the necessity and urgency for international collaboration in the 21st century.

Researchers and institutions from USA, UK, Isreal, and China have been at the forefront of research and education in the ecology and evolution of infectious diseases (EEID). This project contributed to the USA-UK-Israel-China Workshop on Frontiers in Ecology and Evolution of Infectious Diseases, which was held in the Wellcome Trust, London, UK during May 22-23, 2024. With the financial support from the National Science Foundation (NSF), 15 researchers from 12 institutions in the USA participated in the workshop and carried out scientific discussion with participants from UK (15 participants, 14 institutions), Israel (6 participants, 5 institutions), and China (15 participants, 15 institutions). Program managers from U.S. National Science Foundation (NSF), UK Research and Innovation (UKRI), UK Department for Environment Food & Rural Affairs, United States-Israel Binational Science Foundation (BSF), and National Natural Science Foundation of China (NSFC) also participated in the workshop.

Participants first shared information on their individual research activities, infectious diseases and organisms, and together they reviewed, assessed, and understood recent research progresses in EEID over these four countries. Second, participants collectively identified major gaps in data, information, and knowledge of EEID and then proposed and discussed major and new research opportunities that might have great potential to advance fundamental scientific research of EEID and strengthen our capacity to predict and manage epidemic, pandemic, and endemic of infectious diseases. Third, through various group discussion, participants evaluated and identified priority research areas and discussed possible mechanisms and pathways for joint research and education activities in EEID among USA, UK, Israel and China in the next five to ten years.

The workshop had a mix of senior and junior faculty researchers from four countries, which contributed to the junior researchers' career and workforce development. The workshop also facilitated development of research collaboration among the junior researchers from these four countries. As one of the outcomes of this workshop, a few participants in the workshop worked together and submitted joint research proposals to the NSF/UKRI/NSFC/BSF EEID funding program in November 2024. We anticipate more joint international proposals will come from the workshop participants and their colleagues among USA, UK, Israel and China in the coming years.
